def move_one_ball(arr):
    """We have an array 'arr' of N integers arr[1], arr[2], ..., arr[N].The
    numbers in the array will be randomly ordered. Your task is to determine if
    it is possible to get an array sorted in non-decreasing order by performing 
    the following operation on the given array:
        You are allowed to perform right shift operation any number of times.
    
    One right shift operation means shifting all elements of the array by one
    position in the right direction. The last element of the array will be moved to
    the starting position in the array i.e. 0th index. 

    If it is possible to obtain the sorted array by performing the above operation
    then return True else return False.
    If the given array is empty then return True.

    Note: The given list is guaranteed to have unique elements.

    For Example:
    
    move_one_ball([3, 4, 5, 1, 2])==>True
    Explanation: By performin 2 right shift operations, non-decreasing order can
                 be achieved for the given array.
    move_one_ball([3, 5, 4, 1, 2])==>False
    Explanation:It is not possible to get non-decreasing order for the given
                array by performing any number of right shift operations.
                
    """    #--------------------
    # Solution Begin
    def can_move(arr):
        """Can the array be moved?"""
        if len(arr) == 0:
            return True
        if arr[0] < arr[1]:
            return True
        for i in range(1, len(arr)):
            if arr[i] < arr[i - 1]:
                return False
        return True
    #--------------------
    # Solution End
    return can_move(arr)

    numbers in the array will be randomly ordered. Your task is to determine if
    it is possible to get an array sorted in non-decreasing order by performing 
    the following operation on the given array:
        You are allowed to perform right shift operation any number of times.
    
    One right shift operation means shifting all elements of the array by one
    position in the right direction. The last element of the array will be moved to
    the starting position in the array i.e. 0th index. 

    If it is possible to obtain the sorted array by performing the above operation
    then return True else return False.
    If the given array is empty then return True.

    Note: The given list is guaranteed to have unique elements.

    For Example:
    
    move_one_ball([3, 4, 5, 1, 2])==>True
    Explanation: By performin 2 right shift operations, non-decreasing order can
                 be achieved for the given array.
    move_one_ball([3, 5, 4, 1, 2])==>False
    Explanation:It is not possible to get non-decreasing order for the given
                array by performing any number of right shift operations.
                
    """    n = len(arr)
    if n == 0:
        return True

    total_count = 0
    arr_new = []
    while len(arr_new)!= n:
        for i in range(n):
            if arr[i] > arr[i + 1]:
                total_count += 1
                arr_new.append(arr[i])
                arr[i] = arr[i + 1]
                arr[i + 1] = arr_new[-1]
                del arr_new[-1]
        arr_new.append(arr[-1])

    if total_count == 0:
        return True
    else:
        return False

    numbers in the array will be randomly ordered. Your task is to determine if
    it is possible to get an array sorted in non-decreasing order by performing 
    the following operation on the given array:
        You are allowed to perform right shift operation any number of times.
    
    One right shift operation means shifting all elements of the array by one
    position in the right direction. The last element of the array will be moved to
    the starting position in the array i.e. 0th index. 

    If it is possible to obtain the sorted array by performing the above operation
    then return True else return False.
    If the given array is empty then return True.

    Note: The given list is guaranteed to have unique elements.

    For Example:
    
    move_one_ball([3, 4, 5, 1, 2])==>True
    Explanation: By performin 2 right shift operations, non-decreasing order can
                 be achieved for the given array.
    move_one_ball([3, 5, 4, 1, 2])==>False
    Explanation:It is not possible to get non-decreasing order for the given
                array by performing any number of right shift operations.
                
    """    arr = sorted(arr)
    if len(arr) == 0:
        return True
    for i in range(1, len(arr)):
        if arr[i] <= arr[i-1]:
            continue
        else:
            break
    for i in range(0, len(arr)):
        if arr[i] > arr[i-1]:
            arr = arr[i-i:] + arr[0:i]
            break
    return arr == sorted(arr)

    numbers in the array will be randomly ordered. Your task is to determine if
    it is possible to get an array sorted in non-decreasing order by performing 
    the following operation on the given array:
        You are allowed to perform right shift operation any number of times.
    
    One right shift operation means shifting all elements of the array by one
    position in the right direction. The last element of the array will be moved to
    the starting position in the array i.e. 0th index. 

    If it is possible to obtain the sorted array by performing the above operation
    then return True else return False.
    If the given array is empty then return True.

    Note: The given list is guaranteed to have unique elements.

    For Example:
    
    move_one_ball([3, 4, 5, 1, 2])==>True
    Explanation: By performin 2 right shift operations, non-decreasing order can
                 be achieved for the given array.
    move_one_ball([3, 5, 4, 1, 2])==>False
    Explanation:It is not possible to get non-decreasing order for the given
                array by performing any number of right shift operations.
                
    """
    def is_increasing(arr):
        """ It returns true if the elements in the given array are in non-decreasing
        order else false.
        """
        if len(arr) == 0:
            return True

        l_arr = len(arr)
        current = arr[l_arr - 1]

        for i in range(0, l_arr - 1):
            if arr[i] <= current:
                return False
            current = arr[i]

        return True

    if not arr:
        return True

    return all(is_increasing(arr[i:]) for i in range(1, len(arr)))

def move_one_ball(arr):
    """We have an array 'arr' of N integers arr[1], arr[2], ..., arr[N].The
    numbers in the array will be randomly ordered. Your task is to determine if
    it is possible to get an array sorted in non-decreasing order by performing 
    the following operation on the given array:
        You are allowed to perform right shift operation any number of times.
    
    One right shift operation means shifting all elements of the array by one
    position in the right direction. The last element of the array will be moved to
    the starting position in the array i.e. 0th index. 

    If it is possible to obtain the sorted array by performing the above operation
    then return True else return False.
    If the given array is empty then return True.

    Note: The given list is guaranteed to have unique elements.

    For Example:
    
    move_one_ball([3, 4, 5, 1, 2])==>True
    Explanation: By performin 2 right shift operations, non-decreasing order can
                 be achieved for the given array.
    move_one_ball([3, 5, 4, 1, 2])==>False
    Explanation:It is not possible to get non-decreasing order for the given
                array by performing any number of right shift operations.
                
    """
    # check if empty
    if len(arr) == 0:
        return True

    # check if all equal
    if sum(arr) == arr[0]:
        return True

    # find the max index
    max_index = arr.index(max(arr))
    # print ("max_index is:", max_index)

    # find the min index
    min_index = arr.index(min(arr))
    # print ("min_index is:", min_index)

    # shift up till the max index
    for i in range(max_index, len(arr)):
        arr[i], arr[i - 1] = arr[i - 1], arr[i]

    # shift down till the min index
    for i in range(0, min_index):
        arr[i], arr[i + 1] = arr[i + 1], arr[i]

    # check if all equal
    if sum(arr) == arr[0]:
        return True

    return False

    numbers in the array will be randomly ordered. Your task is to determine if
    it is possible to get an array sorted in non-decreasing order by performing 
    the following operation on the given array:
        You are allowed to perform right shift operation any number of times.
    
    One right shift operation means shifting all elements of the array by one
    position in the right direction. The last element of the array will be moved to
    the starting position in the array i.e. 0th index. 

    If it is possible to obtain the sorted array by performing the above operation
    then return True else return False.
    If the given array is empty then return True.

    Note: The given list is guaranteed to have unique elements.

    For Example:
    
    move_one_ball([3, 4, 5, 1, 2])==>True
    Explanation: By performin 2 right shift operations, non-decreasing order can
                 be achieved for the given array.
    move_one_ball([3, 5, 4, 1, 2])==>False
    Explanation:It is not possible to get non-decreasing order for the given
                array by performing any number of right shift operations.
                
    """    if len(arr) == 0:
        return True
    max_ind = len(arr) - 1
    for i in range(0, max_ind):
        if arr[i] <= arr[i + 1]:
            return False
    return True
